Attach a block to the "when left arrow" block and press "Run" to move the player to the net.
Now, attach a block to the `when right event` so that the hand can get to both baskets.
Attach a block to the `when ball hits hand` event to ensure the ball reaches the basket.
Attach code to make the ball bounce when it hits the wall so you can solve this puzzle.
Attach sound blocks to make the net swish when you hit the basket and have the whistle blow when the ball misses your hand. Bounce the ball until it hits the finish target.
Attach the `score point` block to the `when ball in goal` event and the `score opponent point` block to the `when ball misses hand` event to make a game.
Attach the `throw new ball` block in all of the places where the game needs a new ball.
Make this game your own. You can change all the visuals and the rules. When you're done, click "Finish" to let friends try your game on their phones.

Use the blocks below to have the artist draw "01010101" in binary in the first row.
Run this code to see how the artist uses binary to draw this pattern.
Which of the binary strings below could you loop 8 times to draw this image?
Can you draw this pattern by looping just three binary digits (0s and 1s)?

Each binary string below represents one row of this picture. 

Can you rearrange them so it draws a smiley face instead of a frown?
Which 6 digit binary string, repeated 11 times, will draw this image?
What is the shortest binary string that you can repeat to draw this image?

Finish the code to create this drawing.

Here's a higher resolution canvas to draw on - 16 pixels by 16 pixels!

Now make the dancer start a new move after 6 measures!
Add a background effect to your program.

Use the `set tint` block to change the color of a dancer.
Make the other dancer respond to the music using the `begins following` block, too.
The `when up pressed` block lets you run code when the up arrow is pressed. Try to make the dancer do a quick move when you press up.
Make the Robot "drop" once when you press the right arrow key, and "clap" once when you press the up arrow key. Do the drop-clap as fast as you can!
Use the "all ducks" blocks to make the ducks dance together.
Get your groove on! Create a dance of your own to share with your friends.

long_instructions.https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s: For this puzzle, snap all of the blocks together and click "Run" to watch it go!
Drag an extra `move forward` block out of the toolbox, then attach all blocks to `when run` to finish your code.

Help the bird get to the pig. There is one extra blue `move forward` block.

Throw away the extra block by removing it from the other blocks and dragging it back to the toolbox.
_"Trace the path and lead me to the pig."_

_"Follow this path to get me to the pig!"_

Avoid the TNT.
Count the spaces on the grid carefully!
**Challenge:** Navigate this maze to help the bird find the pig!
Watch out for TNT! Help Red get to the pig.
Get the bird to the pig.

_"Oh no! I see a problem."_

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the treasure.

_"You can do this!"_

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the treasure.

_"Be persistent and you will figure this out."_

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the treasure.

_"Don't get frustrated. You can do it!"_

Fix the error(s) to collect all of the treasure.

_"This puzzle is making me loopy!"_

All of the commands that you need are already here...now use your debugging skills to figure out how to solve this puzzle.
Challenge: Use the code in the work area to get at least **6** pieces of treasure!

_"So much treasure!"_

Help Laurel fix the code to get all the treasure.

_"It's treasure island!"_

Help Laurel fix the code to get all the treasure.

Get to the hoop!     

Attach a block to the `when left arrow` event and press "Run" to move the player to the net.
Now, attach a block to the `when right event` so that the hand can get to both baskets.
We're going to send a basketball flying down towards the hand.  Attach a block to the `when ball hits hand` event to ensure the ball reaches the basket.

Now the basket is at the top.  

Attach code to make the ball bounce when it hits the wall so you can solve this puzzle.

Attach sound blocks to make the net swish when you hit the basket and have the whistle blow when the ball misses your hand.  

* * *

Bounce the ball until it hits the finish target.

There is now a hoop at the top.  

Attach the `score point` block to the `when ball in goal` event and the `score opponent point` block to the `when ball misses hand` event to make a game. 

* * *

See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.

Now, you are in control of the ball!  Attach the `throw new ball` block in all of the places where the game needs a new ball.

* * *

See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice!
Help Scrat across the slippery ice to get to the acorn!

Use a <xml><block type="maze_turn" block-text="turn left">
    <title name="DIR">turnLeft</title>
  </block></xml> block to get to the acorn!
Can you get to the acorn with just one <xml><block type="maze_moveForward" block-text="move forward"/></xml> block? Try using a loop!
Add one more block to get Scrat all the way to the acorn!
Can you add a loop to get to the acorn?
Scrat really wants that acorn!
Can you fix this code?
The acorn is so far away! Can you use loops to help Scrat get there?
Help Scrat get all the way over to the acorn!
Help Scrat get to the acorn!
Get to the acorn any way you can!

What a lovely day!  

Help the Artist cover his flowers before the winter by moving forward by 60 pixels.
Add some beauty by repeating that step five times, changing to a random color between each move.
Draw the colorful line 5 times again, this time using a `repeat` loop.
You can create this star by looping a sequence of `move forward` and `turn right by 144 degrees` blocks.

Loops sure make writing code easier!

Use loops to draw this staircase.

-   Each stairstep is 50 pixels long and 50 pixels tall
-   You will need to turn 90 degrees in each direction

This staircase is much bigger, but it takes the same amount of code as the last puzzle!

Fix this loop to complete the puzzle.
Look for a pattern and make this code shorter using loops!
**Challenge:** Look for a pattern and make this code shorter using loops.
Solve this puzzle by drawing a square with 200 pixel sides.

_"This is going to **BEE** great!"_

Help the bee collect all of the nectar.

"_This is going to **BEE** great!_"

Help the bee collect all of the nectar.
This time, help the bee collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible.
This time, help the bee collect all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible.

_"Zombie hungry!"_

Get the zombie to the sunflower using the fewest number of blocks possible.
Get the zombie to the sunflower using the fewest blocks possible!

_"Must eat sunflower!"_

Get the zombie to the sunflower using only the blocks available.
**Challenge:** Figure out how to get all of the nectar using only the blocks available.
Collect all of the nectar from each flower and make honey at the honeycomb.
Make all of the honey.
Make all of the honey.
_"I need some help on the farm! Help me harvest this corn using only the blocks in your toolbox."_

_"Let's hunt for treasure - using loops!"_ 

Help the collector reach at least two piles of treasure using only the blocks in your toolbox. It is possible to collect all 4.

_"This cloud is blocking my view!"_

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud. If there's a flower, get nectar.

More clouds! 

Check underneath every cloud to see if it is hiding a flower before you get nectar. If there is a flower underneath the cloud, the bee will need to get nectar _once_.  

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!
You can only collect nectar from flowers, but you can check any space to see if there is a flower. If there is a flower under any of these clouds, the bee will need to collect nectar _once_.

In this puzzle, we know that every flower has exactly one nectar, but the flowers aren't spaced evenly.

Get all of the nectar using as few blocks as possible.

_"Now I just want to make honey."_

Some of these clouds might have honeycombs under them.  Be sure to check if a honeycomb is hiding behind each cloud! If there is a honeycomb, the bee will only need to make honey _once_.

Sometimes a cloud covers a flower, sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar at flowers and make honey at honeycomb. Remember: if there is a flower, the bee only needs to get nectar _once_. If there is a honeycomb, the bee only needs to make honey _once_.

Sometimes a cloud covers a flower, sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar at flowers and make honey at honeycomb. Remember: there will only ever be _one_ honeycomb or _one_ flower behind each cloud.

**Challenge:** There will be either a flower or a honeycomb under each of those clouds!

Collect nectar once if there is a flower.
Otherwise, make honey once (because there is a honeycomb).

Collect all of the nectar or make all the honey. You can only collect nectar from flowers and make honey from honeycombs. Check any space to see if there is a flower or honeycomb. There will only ever be one flower or one honeycomb behind each cloud.

Conditionals can be helpful, even when you know exactly what is in each spot!

Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey.
Collect all of the nectar and make all of the honey. You can only collect nectar from flowers and make honey from honeycombs. Check every space to see if there is a flower or honeycomb.
Collect all of the nectar and make all the honey. You can collect all of the nectar in one flower by using the `while nectar > 0` loop.

_"Hi, I'm a farmer. I need your help to flatten the field on my farm so it's ready for planting!"_  

Move to the pile of dirt and use the `remove` block to remove it.

_"Move to the pile of dirt and tell me how many shovelfuls to remove."_

Use as few blocks as possible to solve this puzzle.

_"I don't know how much dirt is in this pile!"_

Help the farmer remove this entire pile using a `while` loop.

_"I don't know how much dirt is in this pile!"_

Help the farmer remove this entire pile using a `while` loop.

Look at all of those holes!  Each one needs a different amount of dirt.   

You can use the `while` loop to easily fill them all!
**Challenge:** Fill all of these holes using as few blocks as possible.
Fill all of the holes and remove all of the piles.

_"Dear person. Me zombie. Me hungry. Must... get... to sunflower..."_

Can you get the zombie to the sunflower using only the blocks that are available?
Use the `if` block to help the zombie decide when to turn, then get the zombie to the sunflower.
Help the zombie get to the sunflower.
Help the zombie get to the sunflower.
**Challenge:** Avoid the chompers and help the zombie get to the sunflower.
Help the zombie get to the sunflower.
Help the zombie get to the sunflower.

_"Corn you help me harvest today?"_

Help the harvester check her row of corn to see if anything is ready to pick.  Use conditionals to look at each sprout.  Every stalk will have either **0 or 1** pieces of corn ready to harvest.

_"Lettuce collect both crops from this row!"_

This garden is all mixed up, it has both **corn and lettuce**!  

Help the harvester pick the items that are ready for harvesting.  Each plant will have either **one** corn or **one** lettuce.

_"Corn, lettuce, AND pumpkins! Help me harvest them all."_

Each plant will have either one piece of corn, one head of lettuce, or one pumpkin.

_"Gosh! Now the lettuce is growing in clusters!"_  

The harvester wants to pick everything from her lettuce garden. Each plant will now have more than one head of lettuce on it, so the harvester will need to keep picking while there is still lettuce growing.  

##### (Remember: This garden only has lettuce!)

_"What a bountiful crop!"_

This field has clusters of corn and lettuce growing together -- with one pumpkin at the end.  Can you harvest everything?

_"Let's take this one step further!"_

Can you figure out how to pick the pumpkin?  Make sure to collect all of the corn along the way!
**Challenge:** Collect all of the corn and lettuce, then pick the pumpkin.
Collect all of the corn and lettuce, then pick the pumpkin.
Collect all of the corn and lettuce, then pick the pumpkin.
Collect all of the corn and lettuce, then pick the pumpkin.

The pumpkins mark the place where you should `turn right`. Otherwise keep going forward, but remember to collect all of the lettuce or corn along the way. 

**Each hidden crop has only one corn or lettuce.**

_"It's a very varied vegetable maze!"_ 

Turn right at pumpkins, turn left at lettuce. Collect everything to complete the level.

We've provided you with a grid of "pixels" that you can walk through and make designs by turning on only certain squares.

Use the blocks below to have the artist draw "01010101" in binary in the first row.

Here's a function that takes a binary string of 1's and 0's and instructs the artist to follow them from left to right, top to bottom.  

* * *

The artist will fill-in the squares when it sees a 1 and ignore the square when it sees a 0. 

* * *

**Run this code to see how the artist uses binary to draw this pattern.**
You can only use each binary value (0 or 1) once each in this puzzle. Try using nested loops to complete this drawing.

There are 256 bits represented on this grid - that means it's easy for a small change to cause big problems. Are you persistent enough to restore this logo back to normal?

[][0]

_Let's have a dance party!_

Drag the `make a new` block into the workspace, and connect it inside the `setup` block to create your first dancer.

-   _You can also click the lightbulb to the left if you want more information or extra challenges._

Let's get this moose dancing!

Drag out the <xml><block type="Dancelab_changeMoveLR" block-text="new_dancer do floss"><title name="SPRITE">new\_dancer</title><title name="MOVE" config="MOVES.Dab, MOVES.Drop, MOVES.Floss">Floss</title><title name="DIR">-1</title></block></xml> block onto the workspace. Connect it underneath the <xml><block type="Dancelab_atTimestamp" block-text="after 4 measures"><title name="TIMESTAMP">4</title><title name="UNIT">"measures"</title></block></xml> event block. Your dancer should start a new move after the fourth measure.

**Measures** are used to count time in music. In this tutorial, a measure is four beats long.

_Now we're grooving!_ 

Add an <xml><block type="Dancelab_atTimestamp" block-text="after 6 measures"><title name="TIMESTAMP">6</title><title name="UNIT">"measures"</title></block></xml> event block to your workspace. Make the dancer start a new move after 6 measures.

_This dance needs some flash!_

Look for a new block in your toolbox that adds a background effect behind your dancer. Watch the effects change in time with the music!

Use another new block to make the dancer change moves **every 2 measures**!

-   Choosing `(Next)`, `(Previous)`, or `(Random)` tells the dancer to perform a different move every time the code is run.

_We need more dancers!_

Create a backup dancer called `backup_dancer1` to dance with the cat.

Every dancer has a set of _properties_ that control what it looks like.

You can make it look like a dancer is in the background by making their _size_ smaller. Can you make both backup dancers the same size?

Dancers have a "tint" property that can add a layer of color. Try changing the tint of one of your dancers.

-   Tints will mix the color you choose with the colors of the dancer.

Now we know how to change a dancer's properties. We can also make the same properties automatically respond to the music using this block:
<xml>
  <block type="Dancelab_startMapping" block-text="right_unicorn begins following bass">
    <title name="SPRITE">right\_unicorn</title>
    <title name="PROPERTY">"scale"</title>
    <title name="RANGE">"bass"</title>
  </block></xml>

This program uses the music's "bass" volume (the low sounds) to control one dancer's height. Can you make the other dancer respond to the music too?

The <xml><block type="Dancelab_whenKey" block-text="when up pressed"></block></xml> event block lets you run code when the up arrow is pressed. 

You might change the dance move, change a dancer's properties, or do a quick move just once. Be creative and look out for new blocks!

It's time for a dance-off! The Cat dabs when you press the left arrow key. Make the Robot "drop" once when you press the right arrow key, and "clap" once when you press the up arrow key.

**Use the keys to get the Robot to do the drop-clap-drop-clap as fast as you can!**

Check out this block:

<xml>
  <block type="Dancelab_makeNewDanceSpriteGroup" block-text="Make 6 new ducks in a circle">
    <title name="N">6</title>
    <title name="COSTUME">"DUCK"</title>
    <title name="LAYOUT">"circle"</title>
  </block></xml>

Now you can create a bunch of dancers at once!
Try using some of the "all ducks" blocks to write code that will make all of the ducks dance together.
Get your groove on! Create a dance of your own to share with your friends.

To delete a block from the middle of your code, drag all of the blocks underneath it away to the right and let them sit in the workspace for a while.  

Click on the block you want to delete, and drag it back to the toolbox.

Finally, put your other blocks back in place where they belong.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bounce_events1s_a:
You need to add the `move left` block to the `when left arrow` event to make this game work:

 <xml> <block type="bounce_whenLeft" deletable="false" x="20" y="20">
    <next>
      <block type="bounce_moveLeft"/>
    </next>
  </block>

   </xml>
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bounce_events1s_b: Don't forget to press "Run" and get the hand to the basket in order to solve this puzzle.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bounce_events2s_a:
You will need to have two sets of `move` events coded for this to work:

<xml>
  <block type="bounce_whenLeft" deletable="false" x="20" y="20">
    <next>
      <block type="bounce_moveLeft"/>
    </next>
  </block>
  <block type="bounce_whenRight" deletable="false" x="180" y="20">
    <next>
      <block type="bounce_moveRight"/>
    </next>
  </block>
</xml>

<xml><block type="bounce_whenBallInGoal" deletable="false"><next><block type="bounce_playSound"><title name="SOUND">swish</title><next><block type="bounce_incrementPlayerScore"></block></next></block></next></block><block type="bounce_whenBallMissesPaddle" deletable="false"><next><block type="bounce_playSound"><title name="SOUND">whistle</title><next><block type="bounce_incrementOpponentScore"></block></next></block></next>\</block</xml>

-   repeat 4
    -   repeat 3
        -   repeat 12
            -   get nectar
        -   move forward
    -   turn right

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_harvester_nested_loops_challenge: Try following this path to reach all of the corn!
To collect more than one piece of corn, you need to use `pick corn` more than one time.
You will need to put a small loop inside of your main loop to solve this puzzle!

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_nested_loops_challenge2_a: Don't forget that you can `repeat` a single command or a longer pattern. You can even `repeat` a `repeat` block!
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_nested_loops_challenge2_b: To get all 4 gems, first use a loop to move away from the center. Turn left or right, then use a nested loop to move from the first pile of treasure to the second. If you repeat the nested loop enough times, the collector will move around the _entire_ cave!
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_nested_loops_challenge2_c: The shortest program that reaches all the treasure uses only one `collect` block and two turns.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_nested_loops_challenge2_d:
**Solution:**

<xml>
  <block type="when_run" deletable="false" movable="false">
    <next>
      <block type="controls_repeat_dropdown">
        <title name="TIMES" config="3-10">3</title>
        <statement name="DO">
          <block type="maze_move">
            <title name="DIR">moveForward</title>
          </block>
        </statement>
        <next>
          <block type="maze_turn">
            <title name="DIR">turnLeft</title>
            <next>
              <block type="controls_repeat_dropdown">
                <title name="TIMES" config="3-10">3</title>
                <statement name="DO">
                  <block type="collector_collect">
                    <next>
                      <block type="controls_repeat_dropdown">
                        <title name="TIMES" config="3-10">3</title>
                        <statement name="DO">
                          <block type="maze_move">
                            <title name="DIR">moveForward</title>
                          </block>
                        </statement>
                        <next>
                          <block type="maze_turn">
                            <title name="DIR">turnLeft</title>
                            <next>
                              <block type="controls_repeat_dropdown">
                                <title name="TIMES" config="3-10">3</title>
                                <statement name="DO">
                                  <block type="maze_move">
                                    <title name="DIR">moveForward</title>
                                  </block>
                                </statement>
                              </block>
                            </next>
                          </block>
                        </next>
                      </block>
                    </next>
                  </block>
                </statement>
              </block>
            </next>
          </block>
        </next>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block>
</xml>

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_conditionals5_a: Think of every side of the rectangular path as a path by itself. Set up a nested loop with a `repeat` block on the outside and a `while path ahead` loop on the inside. How many paths does the bee need to buzz down if the bee needs to buzz down every side with a flower?
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_conditionals5_c: There are 3 sides of the rectangle with flowers, so the code needs to `repeat 3 times`. In every repeat, the bee will need to continue along the path, `while path ahead`. To continue down the path, the bee will need to `move forward`. While on the path, the bee needs to check for a flower. `if there is a flower`, the bee should `get nectar`.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_conditionals5_b: Inside the `while path ahead` block you will need to move forward and check for a flower. How do you check if there is a flower? What do you do if there is a flower?

You'll want to use a conditional block (`if` or `if/else`) to solve the challenge.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_conditionals8_b:
This puzzle is tricky, because you can't check blank squares, nectar, _and_ honey with just one single conditional.

Only check for nectar and honey at the end of your path.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge1_a: Can you find a path that reaches every flower and honeycomb without hitting any trees? The best path is a spiral.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_bee_conditionals_challenge1_b: In this puzzle, each space could have a flower, a honey comb, or nothing.  That means you can repeat your `if/else` conditional at each square.

Just like the `if at flower` blocks, the code inside a `while nectar > 0` will only run if the bee is at a flower. The difference is that the code inside will run over and over until there is no nectar left.  Try this pattern:

<xml>  <block type="bee_whileNectarAmount">
    <title name="ARG1">nectarRemaining</title>
    <title name="OP">></title>
    <title name="ARG2">0</title>                    <statement name="DO">
                      <block type="maze_nectar"/>
                    </statement>
  </block></xml>

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_while1_a: You will need to move forward four times to get to the pile. Can you use a `repeat` loop for this?
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_while1_b: Use the `remove 1` block when you are standing on the pile of dirt to remove it.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_while2_a: You will only need to move once to get to the hole.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_while2_b: You will need the `fill 1` block six times. Can you use a loop to make this simpler?

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_while3_a: A loop can help you simplify your code here.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_while3_b: You shouldn't need any `turn` blocks to get to the pile.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals4_a: Instead of using a `repeat` loop, use a `while` loop to keep digging until the pile is gone.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals4_b: This looks very similar to an earlier puzzle, the only difference is which loop you need.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals5a_a: Try nesting a `while` loop inside of a `repeat` loop.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals5a_b: The farmer needs to move forward a total of five times to get to the end of the row. What else does the farmer need to do?
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals5a_c: Move forward 5 times. Each time you move forward, remove the pile of dirt by using the `while there is a pile` block.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals6_a: Make sure you're using the `while` loop to figure out how many times to fill each hole.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals6_b: Notice that the farmer needs to move forward and down several times in a stair-step pattern.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals6_c:
The stair step pattern uses the following blocks

-   move forward
-   fill hole
-   turn right
-   move forward
-   fill hole
-   turn left

How many times do you need to use this stair step pattern?

Make sure you are using the `while there is a hole` to fill the hole.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals8_a: The `while path ahead` block lets you keep going, even if you don't know how many squares are in a path.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals8_b: Putting a `while path ahead` loop inside of a repeat loop can help you in this puzzle.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals8_c: What do you need to do at the end of each path?

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals8_a: You are going to need to use more than one `while` loop.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals8_b: Every hole is at the end of a path, so use `while path ahead` before using `while there is a hole`.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals8_c: Notice that you need to repeat the `while path ahead`, `while there is a hole` code six times.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_while_challenge1_a: Each hole or pile is located one space **backward** from the end of the path.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_while_challenge1_b: If you use a `while` loop, you can tell the farmer to remove a pile or fill a hole, even if one isn't there. That means you can program her to remove any dirt or fill any hole, no matter where she is.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_conditionals8_c: It is possible to solve this without using any `repeat` loops. To do this, you will need to use four `while` loops.

-   Does everything work at the first step?
-   Does everything work at the second step?
-   Where does it go wrong?
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_maze_until4_b: Is there a stair step pattern you can follow for this puzzle?

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_maze_until5_b: To use only one `move forward`, put it inside the `repeat until sunflower` block.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_maze_until6_b: To use only one `move forward`, put it inside the `repeat until sunflower` block.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_maze_until7_a: You don't need your code to be any longer than last time, just because the maze is!
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_maze_until7_b: Although there are more turns here than the last puzzle, your code can be almost identical because of the `repeat until` block!

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_maze_until8_c: Remember to use the `repeat until` block to get you to the sunflower!

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops1_a: You will need to look for corn 5 times, using a repeat loop.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops1_b: Make sure to use an `if at corn` block or you might try to pick something that's not there!

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops2_a: The best way to do this is to nest `if` statements by placing one inside of the other.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops2_b: For this puzzle, you should have one `if/else` statement and one plain `if` statement.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops2_c:
Your `if` statement could look a lot like this:

-   if at corn
    -   pick corn
-   else
    -   if at lettuce
        -   pick lettuce

If there is nothing there, you won't pick anything!

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops3_a:
To get all of the items, try nesting `if` statements three deep.

This means you should put one `if` statement inside of another, then put a third `if` statement inside the second one.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops3_b: For this puzzle, you should have two `if/else` statements and one plain `if` statement.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.grade3_RunningFarm_4courseD_farmer_condL:
No one knows how many heads of lettuce will grow from each sprout.

Use a `while there is lettuce` loop to keep picking until each piece has been gathered.
The `while` loop will handle empty spaces as well! Since there is no lettuce, it will not pick any and let the code move on.
You can use either a `while path ahead` loop or a `repeat` loop to go through all of the crops.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops5_a: There is a new loop: `repeat until at pumpkin`. Can you see how to use it in this puzzle?
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops5_b: There could be more than one corn or lettuce plant in each spot. Use a `while` loop to gather all of them!

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops6_a: Use a `while path ahead` loop or a `if path ahead / else` block to move the farmer down each piece of the spiral.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops6_b: You only need to check for corn during most of the harvest.  Just pick one pumpkin at the very end of your program.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops7_a:
Notice that the easiest path to get to all of the crops is still a spiral.

[][0]
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops7_b: Try using `when path ahead` to keep the harvester moving the right number of steps.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops_challenge1_a: The "Step" button could be very helpful in this challenge.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops_challenge1_b: Normally you would just `pick pumpkin` if you are at a pumpkin. What else do you need to do if you're at a pumpkin?

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.courseD_farmer_condLoops_challenge2_a: The amount of each vegetable in each space can change. A `while` loop can help!

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.validation:
**How do I pass this level?**

-   Make sure a dancer appears on the screen.

_This level ends after 4 measures._
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.challenges:
**Optional Challenges**

-   Choose a different song to play.
-   Rename your dancer.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.validation:
**How do I pass this level?**

-   The dancer needs to switch to a new move after 4 measures.

_The level ends after 7 measures._

**How do I pass this level?**

-   After 6 measures, your dancer needs to be doing a different dance than it was after 4 measures.

_The level ends after 11 measures._

**How do I pass this level?**

-   You need to make the background effect change sometime before the seventh measure of the song.

_This level ends after 9 measures._
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.challenges:
**Optional Challenge**

Change the background effect at different points during the song by connecting the new block under the <xml><block type="Dancelab_atTimestamp"><title name="TIMESTAMP">???</title><title name="UNIT">"measures"</title></block></xml> events.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.validation:
**How do I pass this level?**

-   You need to have at least two dancers.

_This level ends after 5 measures._
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.challenges:
**Optional Challenge**

-   Add a third dancer (or as many as you want!)
-   Make all of your dancers perform different moves at different points in the song.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.validation:
**How do I pass this level?**

-   Two dancers need to have a size other than 100.

_This level ends after 5 measures._
https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.challenges:
**Optional Challenge**

-   Experiment by changing other properties (width, height, rotation, etc.)

https://studio.code.org/s/coursed-2019/s.validation:
**How do I pass this level?**

-   Change the tint of at least one dancer.

_This level ends after 7 measures._

**How do I pass this level?**

-   Properties for two or more dancers must change.

_This level ends after 7 measures._

**How do I pass this level?**

-   Just be creative!

_This level ends after 7 measures._

-   Use the `when left arrow pressed` block to make the Robot do a dance move when you press it.

_This level ends after 7 measures._

-   Just be creative!
